column2: I learned an entirely new way to eat sushi and never thought so much about the actual purpose of "building" a bite of food. As a plate was put in front of us
column3: often the food server would both describe the dish
column4: as well as advise us on the recommended way to eat it
column5: which we have experienced at many other high-end restaurants that consider food as art (Morimoto Waikiki
column6: for example). And flipping the individual bites of sushi upside down into your mouth made it an even more delectable experience than I ever imagined.
